review_detailed_main: This movie is a tool to convert Youtube Fans into Turkish Liras. Thats the point.

review_title: Here is a movie long youtube video
review_detailed_main: While reviewing this movie the first thing to consider is "Should this movie be considered as a long enough youtube video while reviewing it or should i review it as it is a movie?". If it is first option, it is a profitable and enjoyable youtube content. But since this is a review on IMDb we shall consider it as a movie so it sucks. First thing to mention is cast which is full of famous or almost-famous 'youtubers'. Those guys or girls are not actresses or actors they should just continue to produce entertaining and enjoyable content for youtube. This situation that they have put themselves into is something like "I can ride a bike well , so why not i ride a motorbike ?". This is a logic that nobody should believe or follow. I won't even mention the actings of those i have been talking about. Maybe story can be somehow inspiring, but it can only inspire under 10 years old kids who can be inspired by almost anything at that age.

Second-hand embarrassment at its finest. Even a person who never tried to write a script or tried to hold a camera in their life could maintain a quality like this. Just so you know, you could at least put some effort in it. I don't know, make it somehow interesting or put some experienced actors, this movie is something a high-schooler would make. I'm not sure if this movie really took time, with this poor quality. Oh and, the creator himself is actually trying to make this movie look good by calling out his fans. Smh.

To be honest, it doesn't deserve either 1 or 10. He is the most popular youtuber in Turkey and he has lots of fan in Turkey. I rated "1" because 6 is too much for this movie and i think all of his fans rated 10 so this movie's average puan is so high for that movie. In addition, this movie's scene transition is so bad.. it is like a YouTube video or smth.. not professional and i think we can not categorize that like it is real movie. It has a lot of imperfect scene, casts (except 2-3 of them) was not acting very well. I don't suggest that movie unless you want to lose your times.

review_title: The true summary of the Turkish education system and the youth !

He proved himself to be an unneeded youtuber once more with this waste-of-time movie. This kind of counterproductive work should have been prevented right at the very beginning before it misled the young individuals.

This movie is about a famous youtuber Enes Batur! I dont love his videos but he haves 7.000.000 subscribes! And half of them are only 5 or 6 years old! Now he gets a movie. I only watched this movie because i had a cinema ticket for only 2D movies and this movie was only good 2D movie that plays in theaters that day! And this movie was so bad. Actors are the worst part of the movie! They are so bad! And they are not even actors they are just youtubers! And this movie made a good box office so that means we are going to see more youtuber videos! Turkish cinema is death because if anything gets popular they make movies about that! This movie is a low budget movie! And when i went to theathers there were only kids like age 5 with parents and only kids were laughing to the movie! I only smiled like 2 times so this is a waste of time dont watch this movie!

To be honest, it's absurd to criticize a YouTube-made film as Umberto D. Enes Batur has a unique follower mass, he has good communication with them and deals with an important crowd that no one else could strive to make a film, as most people cannot. I think critics like 'not hold a camera before' or 'not wrote a script' is absurd. When someone starts this job at the age of 19, when can they try? I think it's a good viewing rate for the first movie and the things he does in YouTube are very successful. It is wrong to approach a film in this way. Anyone with logic can see from the votes that everyone voted this film in the manner of having preconceived opinions and voted without a watch.

I don't get all the hate towards this movie. The main guy Mr. Batur is a great actor and he's also an activist. Inspired from Inception, it tells a story of a person who is stuck between the reality and imaginary world. Many philosophical questions arise and several ethical dilemmas are presented to viewers.

The film's cinematography is visually stunning, capturing the contrast between the vibrant, dreamlike sequences and the more grounded, stark reality. The transitions between these two worlds are seamless, keeping the audience engaged in the main character's internal struggle. Moreover, the soundtrack complements the narrative perfectly, adding emotional depth to key moments. While some may criticize the plot as overly ambitious, I believe it successfully challenges the viewer to think critically about the nature of truth and perception.
I don't like it. It was so boring. It was silly. I don't understand anything.

review_title: Does really everyone have to make a film?
review_detailed_main: Yes, this is my question. If you can afford to make a film, does it mean you have to do it? The whole cinema industry is a serious business, no matter how many awful movies are there. Unfortunately, this Youtuber believed himself to make a film to screw up the cinema. Apart from that Youtuber, did his friends, directors, producers (basically the whole film crew) really ask themselves what are we doing? When I come across a bad film, I always ask to myself this: "Did no one say "Come on guys, we are insulting the cinema." or something?" Turkish film and TV series industry are really indifferent about what they are doing.

review_title: Enes Batur is stunning in bad way.
review_detailed_main:
Enes Batur is a popular Turkish YouTuber who has gained a massive following through his entertaining videos and vlogs. In his latest project, a film titled "Enes Batur: Hayal Mi Gerçek Mi?" (Enes Batur: Dream or Reality?), he explores the blurred lines between fantasy and reality, showcasing his journey of self-discovery and reflection.

The film starts off with a glimpse into Enes Batur's childhood, where he is seen as a young boy with big dreams and aspirations. Throughout the movie, he revisits his past and the people who have influenced him, showcasing his growth as a person and as a content creator. The film is a mix of documentary-style footage and dramatized scenes, giving viewers a glimpse into the life of Enes Batur beyond his online persona.

One of the strengths of "Enes Batur: Hayal Mi Gerçek Mi?" is its ability to humanize the YouTuber and show the person behind the screen. Enes opens up about the challenges he faced growing up and how he overcame them to achieve success. Through interviews with friends, family, and colleagues, we see a more vulnerable side of Enes Batur that is not often shown in his videos.

The film also delves into the impact of fame on Enes Batur's life, showcasing the highs and lows of being a social media influencer. Enes discusses the pressure of constantly producing content and the toll it takes on his mental health. We see him struggle with the expectations of his audience and the need to constantly reinvent himself to stay relevant in the ever-evolving world of social media.

One of the most compelling aspects of the film is Enes Batur's exploration of his own identity and the role he plays in shaping the lives of his fans. Through candid interviews with his followers, we see the impact Enes has had on their lives and how he has inspired them to pursue their own dreams. The film raises important questions about the power of social media influencers and the responsibilities that come with having a large platform.

Visually, "Enes Batur: Hayal Mi Gerçek Mi?" is stunning, with beautifully shot scenes that capture the essence of Enes Batur's journey. The film is accompanied by a powerful soundtrack that adds depth and emotion to the narrative. The mix of documentary footage and dramatized scenes creates a compelling storytelling experience that keeps viewers engaged from start to finish.

While the film is overall a captivating and well-crafted piece of work, it does have its shortcomings. Some viewers may find the dramatized scenes to be too cheesy or over-the-top, taking away from the authenticity of the story. Additionally, the pacing of the film can be a bit slow at times, with certain scenes dragging on longer than necessary.

Overall, "Enes Batur: Hayal Mi Gerçek Mi?" is a thought-provoking and introspective look at the life of one of Turkey's most popular YouTubers. Enes Batur's journey of self-discovery and reflection is both inspiring and relatable, making the film a must-watch for fans and newcomers alike. Despite its flaws, the film succeeds in shedding light on the complexities of fame and the power of social media in shaping our identities.

In conclusion, "Enes Batur: Hayal Mi Gerçek Mi?" is a visually stunning and emotionally resonant film that showcases the depth and complexity of one of Turkey's biggest social media influencers. Enes Batur's honesty and vulnerability shine through in this captivating exploration of dreams, reality, and the blurred lines in between.
